sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying rectangular loop
message_1: A rectangular loop of wire measures 10 cm by 20 cm and carries a current of 2 A. Calculate the magnetic field at a distance of 5 cm from the center of the loop in a plane perpendicular to the plane of the loop.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a distance of 5 cm from the center of the loop in a plane perpendicular to the plane of the loop, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a rectangular loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * a * b) / (4 * π * (a² + b² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, a and b are the dimensions of the rectangular loop, and x is the distance from the center of the loop.

Given:
I = 2 A
a = 10 cm = 0.1 m
b = 20 cm = 0.2 m
x = 5 cm = 0.05 m

Now, we can plug in the values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * 0.1 m * 0.2 m) / (4 * π * (0.1² + 0.2² + 0.05²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) T * 0.02 m²) / (4 * π * (0.01 + 0.04 + 0.0025)^(3/2))

B = (1.6 × 10^(-7) T) / (0.0525^(3/2))

B ≈ 1.6 × 10^(-7) T / 0.0378

B ≈ 4.23 × 10^(-6) T

The magnetic field at a distance of 5 cm from the center of the loop in a plane perpendicular to the plane of the loop is approximately 4.23 × 10^(-6) T.
